items.title: apple sign in
items.body:
### Expected behaviour

I have installed everything for social core. Now I want to use apple.py as backend.
Everything works fine. I get a popup screen and when I want to login with my appleid I got an error.  'Sign Up not completed' 


### Actual behaviour

I dont know why I get the following error: 'Sign Up not completed' 
What can I do to fix this issue?
I am busy a couple of days. But there is no good explanation how this work from Apple.

Somehow apple.py will never do the function do_auth(). 
How can this be?

### What are the steps to reproduce this issue?

In my settings.py I got the following settings:

SOCIAL_AUTH_APPLE_ID_CLIENT = 'com.companyname.app'

items.title: [Apple Sign-in] Support for multiple client IDs
items.body:
### Expected behaviour

Apple Sign-in for JS requires Service ID (where we put the redirect URL) as the client ID. Expected the same ID could be used for app development

### Actual behaviour

I kind of expected the same ID to be used in building an iOS app as client ID. But when using the same service ID as the client ID, the authorization did not pass. I had to use the bundle ID for the application. As the backend could only support 1 client-id, I had to choose between web or app implementation of the apple sign-in (which of course I chose the app implementation)

### What are the steps to reproduce this issue?

1. Develop apple sign-in in app
2. Use service ID for backend
3. "Authorization got cancelled"

Fixed when I changed the client-id to use the bundle ID

### Any other comments?

Is it possible to support multiple client-ids in a list and search for the appropriate client-id using the "aud" value when decoding the id_token?

items.title: Send proxies while making requests to authorization endpoints
items.body:
Hi, I was trying to setup a django app and I'm using python social auth to sign in with Google. The django app is running on a Linux machine where we don't have direct access to external websites, should use proxy to make requests to any websites like google.com, linkedin.com, etc.,

So, the problem is during google oauth flow, it's unable to make requests to https://accounts.google.com the connection is timing out after a couple of mins due to access to other websites blocked on the machine

Would like to support sending proxies in the following function
https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/master/social_core/backends/base.py#L216

```python
if self.setting('PROXIES'):
     kwargs.setdefault('proxies', self.setting('PROXIES'))
```
We can set the variable in django settings like this
SOCIAL_AUTH_PROXIES = {'http:' 'http://IP: PORT', 'https': 'https://IP: PORT'}

items.title: The url used by the GoogleOpenId backend seems to be deprecated
items.body:
<!--
    Issue template based on the following templates:
    * https://raw.githubusercontent.com/theos/theos/master/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md
    * https://raw.githubusercontent.com/EddyVerbruggen/Toast-PhoneGap-Plugin/master/issue_template.md
-->

The url used by the `GoogleOpenId` backend seems to be deprecated:
https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/master/social_core/backends/google.py#L176

If you try to access https://www.google.com/accounts/o8/id a 404 is returned.

### Expected behaviour

Probably `GoogleOpenId` needs to be removed and the docs updated.

### Actual behaviour

An error is returned when this backend is used.

### What are the steps to reproduce this issue?

1. Configure a project with:
```
AUTHENTICATION_BACKENDS = (
    ...
    'social_core.backends.google.GoogleOpenId',
    ...
)
```
2. Try to access http://127.0.0.1:8000/auth/login/google/
3. A 500 response is returned.


### Any logs, error output, etc?

The stack trace of the error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/jose/workspace/project/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/django/core/handlers/exception.py", line 34, in inner
    response = get_response(request)
  File "/home/jose/workspace/project/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/django/core/handlers/base.py", line 115, in _get_response
    response = self.process_exception_by_middleware(e, request)
  File "/home/jose/workspace/project/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/django/core/handlers/base.py", line 113, in _get_response
    response = wrapped_callback(request, *callback_args, **callback_kwargs)
  File "/home/jose/workspace/project/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/django/views/decorators/cache.py", line 44, in _wrapped_view_func
    response = view_func(request, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/jose/workspace/project/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/social_django/utils.py", line 49, in wrapper
    return func(request, backend, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/jose/workspace/project/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/social_django/views.py", line 23, in auth
    return do_auth(request.backend, redirect_name=REDIRECT_FIELD_NAME)
  File "/home/jose/workspace/project/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/social_core/actions.py", line 29, in do_auth
    return backend.start()
  File "/home/jose/workspace/project/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/social_core/backends/base.py", line 34, in start
    if self.uses_redirect():
  File "/home/jose/workspace/project/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/social_core/backends/open_id.py", line 242, in uses_redirect
    return self.openid_request().shouldSendRedirect()
  File "/home/jose/workspace/project/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/social_core/backends/open_id.py", line 249, in openid_request
    return self.consumer().begin(url_add_parameters(self.openid_url(),
social_core.exceptions.AuthException: OpenID discovery error: HTTP Response status from identity URL host is not 200. Got status 404
[04/Jun/2020 14:18:14] "GET /auth/login/google/ HTTP/1.1" 500 123261
```

### Any other comments?

It looks like the recommended approach is to use "OpenID Connect" instead of the old endpoint, which is what `social_core.backends.google_openidconnect.GoogleOpenIdConnect` does.

Related open issue in the docs repo: https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-docs/issues/65

items.title: Unable to login as an Azure AD Guest User
items.body:
We are using a translation tool (Weblate) in our company and would like to have guest users of our Active Directory to sign in too.

### Expected behaviour

### Actual behaviour

An error occurs when trying this which says: "No E-mail-address received by a third-party athentication service. Please register by E-mail instead"
We were redirected here by a Weblate-programmer.

1. Having a guest account in Azure AD
2. Signing in with social-core
3. Error occurs

/

/

items.title: [Apple ID] Logging in with iOS and a web-based service + bug with User updating
items.body:
<!--
    Issue template based on the following templates:
    * https://raw.githubusercontent.com/theos/theos/master/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md
    * https://raw.githubusercontent.com/EddyVerbruggen/Toast-PhoneGap-Plugin/master/issue_template.md
-->

### Expected behaviour

* I should be bale to use Apple ID backend to login via both iOS and web-form/other approach.
* Consecutive logins should not update User firs/last name with empty strings 

### Actual behaviour

* I can now specify either iOS app to login or service-based up to login sine the audience passed to JWT token decoding is set to the CLIENT setting.
* On consecutive logins if pipeline uses `social_core.pipeline.user.user_details` user first nad last name is overriden with empty strings

### What are the steps to reproduce this issue?

* For name overriding log in a second time (apple only supplies name on first login when account is paired with given Apple ID) 

* For signing in with both iOS and other services:
1. configure your App to use Apple ID, set it it as `primary App id` for Apple ID on Apple Developer portal
2. configure service with proper domain / return urls on Apple Developer portal
3. set up Apple backend as per documentation fro social-auth
4. set CLIENT setting to bundle ID
5. try to logging in with iOS (success)
6. try logging in via web form (failure)
7. change CLIENT to service ID
8. try to logging in with iOS (failure)
9. try logging in via web form (success)

items.title: Code should be mocked properly for test GoogleOpenIdTest::test_login
items.body:
<!--
    Issue template based on the following templates:
    * https://raw.githubusercontent.com/theos/theos/master/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md
    * https://raw.githubusercontent.com/EddyVerbruggen/Toast-PhoneGap-Plugin/master/issue_template.md
-->

### Expected behaviour

Relative code should be mocked properly for test `GoogleOpenIdTest::test_login` in order to not visit the real Google OpenId URL https://www.google.com/accounts/o8/id.

### Actual behaviour

When running test `GoogleOpenIdTest::test_login`, in method `openid_request`, `self.consumer().begin(...)` will visit the real URL. That could cause the test hangs when no network or the Google is just not accessible at the moment.

### What are the steps to reproduce this issue?

Input clear steps to reproduce the issue for a maintainer.

1. clone social-core
2. create a virtualenv for the project
3. start to run tests within a testenv, in my case, it is `tox -e py36`

items.title: okta backend should return email for email instead of preferred_username
items.body:
### Expected behaviour

With the OktaOAuth2 backend, I expect the email of the user to be taken from the email claim of the JWT.

### Actual behaviour

The OktaOAuth2 backend returns for the django user email the preferred_username instead of the email.

### What are the steps to reproduce this issue?

Configure social django with 
```
AUTHENTICATION_BACKENDS = [
    "social_core.backends.okta.OktaOAuth2",
]
```
and use it ...

### Any logs, error output, etc?

The line https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/master/social_core/backends/okta.py#L54 shows the issue.
It should be replaced by
```
                'email': response.get('email') or '',
```
The DEFAULT_SCOPE should also be updated to:
```
    DEFAULT_SCOPE = ["openid", "profile", "email"]
```

items.title: AuthMissingParameter caused by cleaning up the wrong Partial
items.body:
### Expected behaviour

When there are multiple partial functions in the pipeline, the pipeline should seamlessly save the `partial_token` on the session without requiring the `partial_token` to be passed around on every request to the `/complete/<backend>` endpoint.

### Actual behaviour

The clean up process of the `partial_token` removes the previous token from the database but removes the **current** `partial_token` because it doesn't check which token is saved on the session. The `partial_token` for the current partial is saved **before** the cleanup of the old token happens. 

### What are the steps to reproduce this issue?

1. Check out [this branch](https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-examples/pull/6) of the social-examples repo.

2. Add the `SOCIAL_AUTH_GOOGLE_OAUTH2_KEY` and `SOCIAL_AUTH_GOOGLE_OAUTH2_SECRET` to `example-django/example/settings.py`. This branch edits the `home.html` template so it does not pass up the `partial_token` to the `complete/<backend>` endpoint.

3. Connect a non-work Google Account (I think this is necessary to be prompted for Country and City)

4. It should redirect the user and ask for Country. Fill this in.

5. It should redirect the user and ask for City. Fill this in.

6. `AuthMissingParameter` error happens. 

I added lots more context for this issue in my PR [here](https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-examples/pull/6).

items.title: Open Edx integration with Keycloak
items.body:
I am using edx-ironwood.2-6 in ubuntu 18.08. I am also running keycloak 9.0.0. To enable third-party login using Keycloak I am using the [python-social-auth][1] library suggested in [edx documentation][2]. Since by default keycloak.py was not available in the edx-ironwood, I copied this keycloak.js file at the location

``` 
edx-ironwood.2-6/apps/edx/venvs/edxapp/lib/python2.7/site-packages/social_core/backends
``` 
Followed all steps written in comments to setup keycloak and added following information in keycloak.py
```KEY = 'mooc'
    SECRET = 'client secret'
    PUBLIC_KEY = 'publick key from keycloak'
    AUTHORIZATION_URL = 'http://localhost:8080/auth/realms/myrealm/protocol/openid-connect/auth'
    ACCESS_TOKEN_URL = 'http://localhost:8080/auth/realms/myrealm/protocol/openid-connect/token'
    USER_DETAILS_URL = 'http://localhost:8080/auth/realms/myrealm/protocol/openid-connect/userinfo'

```

Added following line in the lms.env.json
```
"THIRD_PARTY_AUTH_BACKENDS":[
     "social_core.backends.keycloak.KeycloakOAuth2",
     "social_core.backends.google.GoogleOAuth2",
     "social_core.backends.linkedin.LinkedinOAuth2"
]

```

In the Django Admin App, Added a Provider
```
Name: Keycloak
slug: keycloak
site: localhost:81
backend: keycloak
client Id: 'mooc'
Client Secret: 'secret key'
```
Also Added client secret in lms.auth.json
```
"SOCIAL_AUTH_OAUTH_SECRETS": {
    "keycloak":"14f89ef1-02ff-48ad-825f-8160e515ec8e"
 }
```

In Keycloak client settings, added access type 'confidential', and redirect uri 'http://localhost:81/auth/complete/keycloak/'

After server restart, In edx login page, login button for keycloak appearing but when I am clicking on it in the browser a message is coming *There has been a 500 error on the Open Edx Server*

In the apache2 log file following error is coming

items.title: Azure AD Tenant throws exception "AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'get'"
items.body:
Attempting to verify Azure AD tenant token

### Expected behaviour

Token verification should succeed

### Actual behaviour

Exception thrown:

AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'get'

### Any other comments?

Comparing the azuread_tenant.py function `user_data` and the azuread.py `user_data` function reveals significant differences.  Specifically, `user_data` in azured.py checks for `response` being `None`.

Using the standard azuread backend in place of the tenant backend is a work-around since there are no tenant-specific keys for token validation

items.body:
Looks like the problem is in this line: https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/master/social_core/backends/amazon.py#L37

Apparently, Amazon stoped answering bots on that url, in browser works fine.

To fix the issue is enough to change url in the line from the link above to this one: "https://api.amazon.com/user/profile" (can be found here: https://developer.amazon.com/docs/login-with-amazon/obtain-customer-profile.html)

items.title: GitHub: deprecation of using access_token query param
items.body:
GitHub announced deprecation of using `access_token` query param to make API requests:

https://developer.github.com/changes/2019-11-05-deprecated-passwords-and-authorizations-api/

This package's github backend needs to migrate to use [Basic Authentication](https://developer.github.com/v3/auth/#via-oauth-and-personal-access-tokens) in order to continue supporting GitHub.

items.title: Disqus `expires` attribute is always `null`
items.body:
Hey, 
I've been using this package on a project and it's been extremely helpful, but it appears that there might be an issue with the Disqus backend because the `expires` attribute in extra_data always appears to be `null`.
Though I admittedly don't have extensive knowledge of the inner-workings of this package, I looked into the issue a bit and it looks like the Disqus API Authorization page references the attribute being `expires_in`, whereas it appears to be referenced as `expires` in `social_core/backends/disqus.py`.

Could this be the source of the issue or is there something that I'm misunderstanding?

items.title: FIELDS_STORED_IN_SESSION are not cleared and thus can be leaked to future auths
items.body:
First, thanks for maintaining `python-social-auth`; we have found it invaluable for maintaining authentication in zulip without reinventing the wheel.

We recently encountered an interesting bug (https://github.com/zulip/zulip/issues/13560) where an optional field (`mobile_flow_otp`, though it doesn't matter) that we store using `FIELDS_STORED_IN_SESSION` to modify the behavior at the end of the authentication flow remains in the session after authentication completed, and `FIELDS_STORED_IN_SESSION` are not cleared when restarting the authentication flow later.  The result is that if one attempts to authenticate again without using the `mobile_flow_otp` option, `python-social-auth` ends up preserving the value from the previous authentication session. 

We believe the cause of the bug is that the logic here:
https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/3.2.0/social_core/actions.py#L11

Where if a field name isn't present in the `data` object, the loop does nothing, rather than removing any pre-existing value from the session.  I think a correct fix would be just to have an `else` clause that does `session_pop`, but we haven't had a chance to test that yet.  If you'd like a PR doing that, I expect someone in the Zulip project would be up for writing one (it seems like it'd be easy to extend `test_fields_stored_in_session` to test the new behavior).

I think we can work around this for ourselves easily by simply passing an explicit `None` value into for every optional field (effectively clearing things by having `data` contain every value) rather than not passing anything for options that aren't desired.  But potentially reusing session fields from previous authentication attempts seems like unexpected behavior that could result in similar weird bugs for other projects, so this seems worth fixing upstream.  

I don't see any reason a project would rely on the behavior of fields in `FIELDS_STORED_IN_SESSION` not having been cleared, but maybe I'm missing something, but I suppose if that was desired behavior, I think the right model would be to have an explicit variable with a name like `FIELDS_STORED_IN_SESSION_ACROSS_MULTIPLE_AUTHS` for which fields want that sort of long-term storage behavior, so it's opt-in.

items.title: Feature request: allow remapping of psa's user fields to the program's user fields
items.body:
When using a custom user object, the field names that psa looks up might not match the field names on the user object. Also, there might be extra data provided by the backend that is relevant to store directly in the user object.

It'd be handy to have an agreed upon way of mapping the fields in the easiest imaginable case, when a single field from psa maps to a single but differently named field on the user object. Also, it would be good to have documentation for where more complicated rewrites and mappings could be done.

items.title: Instagram closed new app registration. Provider should be refactored or should be deleted
items.body:
According to the Instagram announcement:

> UPDATE: Starting October 15, 2019, new client registration and permission review on Instagram API platform are discontinued in favor of the Instagram Basic Display API. 

Need to refactor instagram backend provider, because now its not a working. 

instagram backend provider use `https://api.instagram.com/v1/users/self` for get user data, but now it should be `https://graph.instagram.com/me`. [link to the doc](https://developers.facebook.com/docs/instagram-basic-display-api/reference/me)

 Also need refactor `get_user_details` and `get_user_id` methods because response is also changed now.


But on [Instagram basic display api page](https://developers.facebook.com/docs/instagram-basic-display-api/)  we can see announcement in Limitations block.
> Instagram Basic Display is not an authentication solution. Data returned by the API cannot be used to authenticate your app users or log them into your app. If you need an authentication solution we recommend using Facebook Login instead

So maybe should just remove this provider from backend.

items.title: OpenId Connect fails when no 'alg' in JWKS
items.body:
OpenIdConnectAuth fails when JWKS does not specify the 'alg'. This line causes the exception: https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/c8d172e3fe5129fe9c7814157684c2d83d7809e9/social_core/backends/open_id_connect.py#L165

At least Ping Identity's OpenId Connect implementation does not have the 'alg' in their JWKS URL: https://sso.connect.pingidentity.com/sso/as/jwks

According to https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#IDTokenValidation (point 7) the key defaults to RS256 if missing.

As a workaround I did something like this and it seems to work. I override OpenIdConnectAuth's get_remote_jwks_keys():

    def get_remote_jwks_keys(self):
        keys = super(MyOpenIdConnectAuth, self).get_remote_jwks_keys()
        for key in keys:
            if 'alg' not in key:
                key['alg'] = 'RS256'

        return keys

Is this a bug or am I missing something here?

items.title: 403 errors when accessing app via a Cloudfront distribution

But my goal is to serve the application from a naked apex domain, like https://example.com.

According to Route 53's rules, any traffic to a naked domain must be served with all traffic routed through a Cloudfront distribution, with your backend site as the origin.

items.title: Linkedin backend not handling email field correctly
items.body:
There seems to be a discrepency between the docs and the Linkedin backend code, specifically for `SOCIAL_AUTH_LINKEDIN_OAUTH2_FIELD_SELECTORS`.

https://python-social-auth.readthedocs.io/en/latest/backends/linkedin.html

> # Add the fields so they will be requested from linkedin.
> SOCIAL_AUTH_LINKEDIN_FIELD_SELECTORS = ['email-address', 'headline', 'industry']

The backend code: https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/master/social_core/backends/linkedin.py#L46

The string 'emailAddress' is looked for in `FIELD_SELECTORS`, while the docs specify 'email-address'. This leads to the email address not being fed into the pipeline, unless the undocumented `emailAddress` camel case version is added to the field selectors list as well.

Furthermore, the 'firstName' and 'lastName' also seem to be camel case instead of snake case as well, which I don't think is correct.

https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/master/social_core/backends/linkedin.py#L30

items.title: BUG: AzureAD multitenant backend getting wrong UID
items.body:
The AzureAD backend is getting the wrong UID [here](https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/cfb4fc028051e25e5766d7dfd479a35af247b4a7/social_core/backends/azuread.py#L63). As it stands currently, `upn` is not in the response, so for each new user their UID is set to none. Then, when the same user tries to login again, there is no match because UID for all users are `None`, which results in the creation of a duplicate account, and then a variety of cascading errors due to the lack of user details, provider, etc.
According to [Microsoft](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/id-tokens), the unique user ID is set by `oid`; `upn` does not exist.

Simply changing the line of code to `return response.get('oid')` fixes this issue.

I can submit a PR if desired, but it's just changing three characters. This can be replicated easily in almost any environment by using the backend `azuread-oauth2`, which also happens not to be documented in the documentation.

items.title: Partial Prepare function under partial pipelines fails for model with custom primary key field
items.body:
### Description
When using partial pipeline such as `social_core.pipeline.mail.mail_validation` with a user model having the primary key other than `id`, the function `partial_prepare` https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/master/social_core/pipeline/utils.py#L17 raises an `attribute error`

### Steps to Reproduce
- Create a model with a primary key field name other than `id`
-  Add `social_core.pipeline.mail.mail_validation` to the `SOCIAL_AUTH_PIPELINE` 
- Perform a request to add a new user.
 
### Earliest Version Affected
- social-auth-core v3.1.0

### Error
```
/social_core/backends/base.py", line 80, in authenticate
return self.pipeline(pipeline, *args, **kwargs)

/social_core/backends/base.py", line 83, in pipeline
    out = self.run_pipeline(pipeline, pipeline_index, *args, **kwargs)

/social_core/backends/base.py", line 113, in run_pipeline
    result = func(*args, **out) or {}

/social_core/pipeline/partial.py", line 28, in wrapper
    *args, **kwargs)
 /social_core/pipeline/utils.py", line 26, in partial_prepare
    'user': user and user.id or None,
AttributeError: 'User' object has no attribute 'id'
```

### Possible Implementation

- Use the attribute `pk` instead of `id` since it's independent of the actually primary key

items.title: RFC: GitHub callback URL with django-tenants
items.body:
We're using https://github.com/tomturner/django-tenants to build a multi-tenant add-on for https://github.com/kiwitcms/Kiwi. It just needs to be installed and hooked up into local_settings.py.

django-tenants uses PostgreSQL schemas and switching db.connection between them based on the hostname you are trying to access. This makes it possible for users to only see the data they have created. Which apps/tables are affected is controlled via settings, so called TENANT_APPS and SHARED_APPS.

In our case the "public" tenant is our demo website and SHARED_APPS=INSTALLED_APPS, including `social-auth-app-django` and `django.contrib.auth`.  They are not part of TENANT_APPS b/c we want to have accounts in a central place and then give some accounts access to their tenants with middleware. This means authorized accounts will share the same username/password between multiple tenants.

Question is how do I hook this with PSA, GitHub backend in particular. The 'Authorization callback URL' must be on the "public" tenant but how do we know where to redirect to ?

Also with user/pass login the same account needs to login separately into each tenant login url. I think this is because of session cookies.

Any ideas and pointers how to proceed in this scenario ?

items.title: CAS Auth
items.body: Adding CAS support would be a great boon, old auth protocol, very similar to a more poorly designed OAuth2 and a lot easier to implement, but it's in heavy use in the educational industry in the USA for whatever reason.  There are a few python libraries that implement it that could be integrated into social-core, such as https://github.com/python-cas/python-cas, or it could be written from scratch, though it has such a large variety of implementations and formats that it would essentially be rewriting https://github.com/python-cas/python-cas anyway as it seems to have a whole lot of the weird corner issues (it's a very poorly defined protocol) already resolved.

items.title: User logs in as wrong user!
items.body:
get_user_id in base.py  returns response.get(self.ID_KEY)

If the response did not contain that key (most likely due to misconfiguration of the provider ID_KEY or by the response being incorrect) then this returns an id of None (at least on python 3).

The first user like this is cached under an userid of None - and ALL subsequent users that are missing this key will be logged in as the same first user.

I assume this should just throw an exception if the field is missing.

items.title: azuread_tenant uses sub instead of upn
items.body:
azuread_tenant uses sub as get_user_id
```
    def get_user_id(self, details, response):

        return response.get('sub')
```
instead of upn (which is what azuread uses)

I've registered a new OAuth Consumer by following the instructions in the [Bitbucket documentation](https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/oauth-on-bitbucket-cloud-238027431.html) and I've clicked all boxes for the "Accounts" scope. I've filled in the basic values:

 - Name: I choose a name that will be easy to link and remember like "Singularity Registry Server"
 - Callback URL: should be `http://[your-domain]/complete/bitbucket` For localhost, this is usually `http://127.0.0.1/complete/bitbucket`
 - I've kept the button "This is a private consumer" checked.
 - Under Permissions (the scope) click on Account (email, read, write).

Then I added the following variables to my settings:


And as you can see in the image above, the link I'm using is `127.0.0.2/login/bitbucket` with a next to go back to the original page (it doesn't work with or without it).

Additionally, I've added the backend to the list with the others:

```python

    'django.contrib.auth.backends.ModelBackend',
    'social_core.backends.username.UsernameAuth',
    'social_core.backends.open_id.OpenIdAuth',
```

items.title: "next" parameter doesn't work if user already logged in
items.body:
### steps to reproduce
1. Log out of from your application
2. navigate to `/yourapp/?next=/next_url/`
3. entering credentials
   you should be redirected to `next_url`
4. Now, with active logged-in sessions, navigate _again_ to  `/yourapp/?next=/next_url/`

### expected behavior
* redirected to `next_url` (same as the result of step 3 above)

### actual behavior
* redirected to your dashboard i.e you default redirect url.

It appears the `?next=` parameter is being ignored when user is logged in. Is this an intended behavior.

items.title: Allow nonce to be optional in OIDC Authorization workflow
items.body:
According to the spec nonce is optional:

https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#AuthRequest

It would be handy to be able to turn this off via a setting that affects the `OpenIdConnectAuth` backend, this would avoid the overhead of generating / dealing with the nonce when it's not used by the OIDC  provider.

items.title: Update Patreon provider URLs
items.body:
The path structure for Patreon URLs has changed recently as part of our update to V2.


- The access token URL has changed from `'https://api.patreon.com/oauth2/token``'` to `'https://www.patreon.com/api/oauth2/token``'`
- The revoke token URL has changed from `'https://api.patreon.com/oauth2/revoke``'` to `'https://www.patreon.com/oauth2/revoke'`
- The user data URL has changed from `'https://api.patreon.com/oauth2/api/current_user'` to `'https://www.patreon.com/api/oauth2/v2/identity``'` 

More information APIV2 here: https://docs.patreon.com/#apiv2-oauth

Please let me know if you have any questions!

items.title: Battle.net OAuth2 is using incorrect URL & passing access_token incorrectly.
items.body:
I was wrecking my head for a while over why I couldn't get OAuth2 working with battle.net when the other services i've set up using Python Social Auth have been super easy and quick. 

After some debugging I found that the user_data function on the battlenet backend is using an incorrect API URL (and as noted in #256 the region is hardcoded) - it is also paramatizing the access token in the URL when it should be sent via an Authorization header (https://develop.battle.net/documentation/api-reference/oauth-api) 

https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/402e15bd2854ade0b8f0d19663966473f0e1c6ff/social_core/backends/battlenet.py#L45-L50

This should be changed to something akin to:


```
def user_data(self, access_token, *args, **kwargs):
    return self.get_json(
        'https://eu.battle.net/oauth/userinfo',
        headers={'Authorization': 'Bearer {}'.format(access_token)},
    )

```
I would make a pull request but my python is rusty and I haven't properly tested this. I would recommend anyone considering making a change to make user_data a bit more robust as battle.net has weird account region rules.

items.title: Facebook rerequest denied scopes
items.body:
## Problem

Currently if a Facebook user denies providing their email, but clicks on "Continue as {User Name}", the app I'm working on is linked in their Facebook account, but my application cannot proceed on creating the user account on our end.
If user tries to signup again, they are not prompted to give permissions anymore, as the app is already linked to their account on Facebook's end.

I tried going through the disconnect pipeline, but the app remains linked to their account.

## Solution

According to [Facebook documentation](https://developers.facebook.com/docs/facebook-login/manually-build-a-login-flow#reaskperms) it should be possible to ask for denied permissions without having to disconnect and re-auth an user:

> You do this by adding the auth_type=rerequest parameter to your Login Dialog URL:
```
https://www.facebook.com/v3.2/dialog/oauth?
    client_id={app-id}
    &redirect_uri={redirect-uri}
    &auth_type=rerequest
    scope=email
```

**Is there any way to currently do this in python-social-auth?**
If not, can you give me some pointers on where would be the best place to put it? I was thinking on creating a separate endpoint for re-authentication and I'd be happy to create a PR, but I'm not sure it's the best solution.

## Version

- social-auth-app-django 2.1.0
- social-auth-core 1.7.0
- Facebook 2.9

items.title: Wrap all HTTP errors
items.body:
We have encountered a server error response from facebook when trying to authenticate. Sadly, this case ends up in server error on our side, because the `HTTPError` raised by `requests` is not wrapped in `SocialAuthBaseException`, which we expect.

I suggest to wrap all unspecific `HTTPError`s into `AuthUnknownError` in `handle_http_errors` function to ease their handling.
